articles.headline: Authorities Ease Madoff’s Bail Terms
articles.snippet: Bernard Madoff will not be going to jail even though he failed to meet the original terms of his $10 million bail agreement.
articles.abstract: Bernard Madoff will not be going to jail even though he failed to meet the original terms of his $10 million bail agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bernard L. Madoff, the New York financier who authorities say has confessed to a $50 billion Ponzi scheme, will not be going to jail even though he failed to meet the original terms of his $10 million bail agreement.

articles.headline: Envelope, Please. It’s a Pogie.
articles.snippet: The fourth annual Pogie Awards give a tip of the hat to the best consumer tech ideas of 2008.
articles.abstract: The fourth annual Pogie Awards give a tip of the hat to the best consumer tech ideas of 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: Good evening, and welcome to the fourth annual Pogie Awards, celebrating the very best in consumer technology!

articles.headline: Big News in Washington, but Far Fewer Cover It
articles.snippet: As newspapers cut costs, reporting in the capital suffers.
articles.abstract: As newspapers cut costs, reporting in the capital suffers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A new president arrived from a new party. The balance of power shifted in Congress. Legions of fresh new faces showed up in the nation’s capital with new ideas, eager to upend the way the country does business.

articles.headline: As the Fed Flattens Rates, the Dollar Gets Bruised
articles.snippet: A day after the Federal Reserve cuts rates, the value of a euro jumped the most since its inception.
articles.abstract: A day after the Federal Reserve cuts rates, the value of a euro jumped the most since its inception.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  The dollar is sliding back into a rapid downward trajectory as the United States enters a new era of ultra-low interest rates and investors reassess the currency’s worth in a drawn-out recession.
articles.byline: By Carter Dougherty and David Jolly

articles.headline: S.E.C. Knew Him as Foe and Friend
articles.snippet: Over the last 20 years, Bernard L. Madoff alternately wowed and angered top policy makers at the Securities and Exchange Commission.
articles.abstract: Over the last 20 years, Bernard L. Madoff alternately wowed and angered top policy makers at the Securities and Exchange Commission.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As the Securities and Exchange Commission begins an internal examination into how it missed the red flags of one of the largest frauds in history, it will inevitably discover that Bernard L. Madoff was a Wall Street pioneer who over the last 20 years alternately impressed and infuriated the agency’s top policy makers.

articles.headline: Paulson Takes Lead in Auto Rescue Talks
articles.snippet: The Bush administration and G.M. and Chrysler are said to be negotiating terms of an overhaul plan.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration and G.M. and Chrysler are said to be negotiating terms of an overhaul plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by David M. Herszenhorn, Bill Vlasic and David E. Sanger and written by Mr. Herszenhorn.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn, Bill Vlasic and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: On Wall Street, Bonuses, Not Profits, Were Real
articles.snippet: As regulators sift through the financial rubble, there are questions about the role of lavish bonuses in the debacle.
articles.abstract: As regulators sift through the financial rubble, there are questions about the role of lavish bonuses in the debacle.
articles.lead_paragraph: “As a result of the extraordinary growth at Merrill during my tenure as C.E.O., the board saw fit to increase my compensation each year.”

articles.headline: The Fight to Survive, Writ Small
articles.snippet: Bankers returning to rules like requiring 20 percent down payments are making it difficult for many small businesses.
articles.abstract: Bankers returning to rules like requiring 20 percent down payments are making it difficult for many small businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hoss Boyd, owner of an electrical contracting and solar energy installation company in Texas, was on the road at 3:30 a.m. the other day on business  but not the usual kind. He was looking for the $48,000 that a contractor owed him so he could make payroll.

articles.headline: Madoff Scandal Shaking Real Estate Industry
articles.snippet: Commercial brokers and developers had heavily invested with Bernard L. Madoff, whose business style mirrored the practices of the real estate world.
articles.abstract: Commercial brokers and developers had heavily invested with Bernard L. Madoff, whose business style mirrored the practices of the real estate world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost no segment of New York City’s real estate industry was spared in the Madoff scandal, which may be history’s largest Ponzi scheme: commercial brokers large and small, little-known developers and prominent families like the Wilpons and Rechlers all lost money to Bernard L. Madoff, industry executives say.

articles.headline: In Clinton List, a Veil Is Lifted on Foundation
articles.snippet: A list of donors offers a glimpse into the world in which Bill Clinton has traveled since leaving the White House.
articles.abstract: A list of donors offers a glimpse into the world in which Bill Clinton has traveled since leaving the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Former President Bill Clinton has collected tens of millions of dollars for his foundation over the last 10 years from governments in the Middle East, tycoons from Canada, India, Nigeria and Ukraine, and other international figures with interests in American foreign policy.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Charlie Savage
